choices.text: Epilepsy is always genetic, while single seizures are not
Epilepsy refers to recurrent seizures due to a chronic underlying condition
Single seizures always lead to epilepsy
There is no distinction; both terms are interchangeable

questions.text: What distinguishes epilepsy from a single seizure event?
questions.solution:
• Epilepsy is defined as a condition characterized by recurrent, unprovoked seizures due to a chronic underlying condition. These seizures can occur due to various causes, such as genetic predisposition, structural brain abnormalities, or metabolic disorders.
  • In contrast, a single seizure may occur due to an acute reversible cause(e.g., fever, infection, or trauma) and does not imply the diagnosis of epilepsy.

Option A is incorrect because epilepsy is not always genetic; it can be caused by various factors including structural or metabolic abnormalities.

Option C is incorrect because not all individuals who experience a single seizure will develop epilepsy.

Option D is incorrect as epilepsy and single seizure events are not interchangeable; epilepsy refers to a chronic predisposition for recurrent seizures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Epilepsy involves a chronic predisposition to recurrent seizures.
  • A single seizure due to a reversible cause does not imply epilepsy.
  • Diagnosis of epilepsy requires at least two unprovoked seizures or a high risk of recurrence.

questions.text: According to the ILAE 2017 classification, which of the following terms is no longer used to categorize seizures
questions.solution:
• The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) 2017 classification of seizures introduced significant changes, particularly in the terminology for focal seizures. The terms "simple focal seizures" and "complex focal seizures" are no longer used.
    • Simple focal seizures, which refer to seizures without impairment of consciousness, are now termed focal aware seizures.
    • Complex focal seizures, which involve impaired consciousness, are now termed focal impaired awareness seizures.
  • Absence seizures(C), which involve brief episodes of staring or impaired awareness, remain part of the classification and are distinct from focal seizures.

Key Takeaways:

  • The ILAE 2017 classification replaced the terms simple and complex focal seizures with more descriptive terms.
  • Focal aware and focal impaired awareness seizures are now used to describe focal seizures based on the patient's level of awareness.

questions.text: What phenomenon describes the spread of seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex, often starting with the fingers?
questions.solution:
• Jacksonian march refers to the spread of seizure activity from one part of the body (often the fingers or hand) to other regions, reflecting the sequential involvement of the motor cortex. This phenomenon is characteristic of focal seizures that originate in the primary motor cortex and propagate along the cortical homunculus.
  • Todd's paralysis (A) is a temporary post-seizure weakness or paralysis in the affected limb, lasting minutes to hours, but it is not related to the spread of seizure activity during the seizure.
  • Epilepsia partialis continua (C) is a type of prolonged focal motor seizure that is continuous and often difficult to control, but it does not describe the spreading seizure activity seen in the Jacksonian march.
  • Aura (D) refers to subjective sensations that precede a seizure (e.g., visual disturbances or strange smells) but does not describe motor seizure activity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Jacksonian march describes the gradual spread of motor seizure activity across the body, often starting with a small area like the fingers.
  • This type of seizure spread is commonly associated with focal seizures originating in the motor cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare condition where a seizure continues for hours or days and is often refractory to medical therapy?
questions.solution:
• Epilepsia partialis continua (EPC) is a rare and severe form of focal motor status epilepticus, characterized by continuous muscle twitching or jerking (usually in a specific body part) for hours, days, or longer. It often resists treatment and can be refractory to standard seizure medications. EPC is frequently associated with underlying structural brain abnormalities or metabolic disorders.
  • Absence seizures (A) are brief, generalized, non-convulsive seizures often lasting only a few seconds and are not continuous or refractory.
  • Grand mal seizures (C), also known as generalized tonic-clonic seizures, involve convulsions but are not typically continuous or refractory for hours or days.
  • Simple partial seizures (D) involve focal onset without loss of awareness but are not prolonged like EPC.

Key Takeaways:

  • Epilepsia partialis continua (EPC) is a rare, prolonged form of focal seizure that is refractory to typical treatments and may last for hours or days.
  • EPC is often resistant to standard anti-seizure therapies and is associated with serious underlying brain pathology.

choices.text: Because focal seizures never have EEG correlates
Due to the origin of seizures from medial temporal or inferior frontal regions distant from the scalp
Because scalp EEGs are not sensitive enough for any seizures
Because all focal seizures are generalized in EEG

questions.text: Why might scalp EEG recordings be non-localizing in some focal seizures?
questions.solution:
• Scalp EEGs may be non-localizing for some focal seizures because certain regions of the brain, such as the medial temporal or inferior frontal lobes, are anatomically distant from the scalp. Seizure activity originating from these deeper brain regions can be poorly detected or appear diffuse on the scalp EEG, leading to non-localizing or ambiguous results.
  • Option A is incorrect because focal seizures do have EEG correlates, but they may not be well localized depending on the seizure's origin.
  • Option C is incorrect because scalp EEGs are sensitive to many types of seizures, but they may not detect activity from deep brain regions.
  • Option D is incorrect because focal seizures are not generalized; generalized seizures affect both hemispheres simultaneously, while focal seizures begin in one part of the brain.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scalp EEG may not localize focal seizures if the seizures originate from deep brain regions such as the medial temporal or inferior frontal lobes.
  • These regions are distant from the scalp, and seizure activity originating here may not generate clear signals on surface EEG.

questions.text:
You are working at a community clinic conducting routine health screenings. A 70-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension presents with concerns of brief episodes of confusion and jerking movements over the past few weeks. His wife reports that he has experienced a few "blank stares" followed by disorientation. On further questioning, you learn he has no prior history of seizures but recently experienced a minor fall. You are considering the possibility of seizures and are discussing the incidence of seizures across different life stages during patient education.
At which life stages is the incidence of seizures the highest?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of seizures is highest during early childhood and late adulthood. In early childhood, the developing brain is more susceptible to seizures due to various factors, such as fevers, genetic predispositions, or developmental abnormalities. In late adulthood, conditions such as stroke, degenerative diseases, or brain trauma can increase seizure risk.
  • Option A (Infancy and adolescence) is incorrect because adolescence does not represent a peak incidence for seizures, though some types like juvenile myoclonic epilepsy may present during this period.
  • Option C (Middle age and adolescence) is incorrect because the incidence of seizures in middle age is lower compared to early childhood and late adulthood.
  • Option D (Only in early childhood) is incorrect because late adulthood is also a critical period with a high incidence of seizures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Early childhood and late adulthood are the periods with the highest incidence of seizures, driven by factors such as brain immaturity in children and age-related brain pathology in older adults.
  • Screening for seizures in older adults is important, as they may present with subtle symptoms like confusion or brief episodes of altered awareness.

questions.text:
You are evaluating a 7-year-old girl in the clinic who has had episodes of loss of focus. Her parents report no abnormal movements or confusion after the episodes. You suspect what and order an EEG to confirm your diagnosis.
On EEG, Based on her clinical presentation, in which age group are following seizures most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
• Absence seizures are most commonly seen in young children, typically between the ages of 4 to 10 years. These seizures are characterized by brief staring spells with impaired awareness and an abrupt onset and offset. They often occur multiple times per day and may be misinterpreted as daydreaming or inattention.
  • On EEG, absence seizures are classically associated with 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave discharges during the seizure. This pattern is highly characteristic and is key to diagnosing childhood absence epilepsy.
  • Option A (Infants): Absence seizures are not typical in infants. Other types of seizures, such as infantile spasms, are more common in this age group.
  • Option C (Adolescents): While some forms of epilepsy can appear during adolescence, absence seizures are more frequent in younger children.
  • Option D (Adults): Absence seizures rarely begin in adulthood. If they are present in adults, they often started during childhood.

Key Takeaways:

  • Absence seizures typically occur in young children and are characterized by brief, sudden episodes of impaired awareness.
  • EEG findings for absence seizures show 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave discharges, confirming the diagnosis.
  • These seizures are often mistaken for inattention or daydreaming in school-aged children.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the neurology clinic by his parents due to daily seizures, including tonic seizures during sleep and atonic (drop) attacks while awake. His developmental milestones have been delayed and he is attending a special education program due to intellectual disability. The parents report that the seizures have been difficult to control despite multiple anti-epileptic medications. An EEG shows following discharges at a frequency of 2-2.5 Hz, along with bursts of fast rhythms during sleep. Based on this presentation, you suspect the boy has a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome.

Which epilepsy syndrome is most commonly associated with this presentation in childhood?
questions.solution:
• Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome that typically begins between the ages of 3 and 8 years. It is characterized by multiple seizure types (tonic, atonic, and absence seizures are common), intellectual disability, and intractable epilepsy (seizures that are difficult to control with medications).
  • EEG findings in LGS include slow spike-and-wave discharges during wakefulness and fast rhythms during sleep, which are hallmark features.
  • Children with LGS often exhibit developmental delays and intellectual disability as part of the syndrome. Seizures are often refractory to treatment, and the prognosis is typically poor due to ongoing cognitive and behavioral issues.
  • Option A (Childhood absence epilepsy): Typically presents with absence seizures in school-aged children without intellectual disability, and the seizures are often well controlled with medication.
  • Option C (Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy): Characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in adolescence, with normal intellectual function. Seizures are generally responsive to treatment.
  • Option D (Temporal lobe epilepsy): Often presents with focal seizures in older children or adults, and intellectual disability is not a common feature.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a severe childhood epilepsy syndrome associated with intellectual disability and multiple types of refractory seizures.
  • It is often diagnosed by the presence of slow spike-and-wave EEG discharges and multiple seizure types, including tonic and atonic seizures.
  • Management of LGS is challenging due to intractable epilepsyand the poor cognitive prognosis.

choices.text: A normal EEG always predicts that a patient will not develop epilepsy
An abnormal EEG with frequent epileptiform activity suggests a worse prognosis for seizure control
EEG is highly useful in predicting epilepsy in patients with predisposing conditions like head trauma
MEG is unable to localize the source of epileptiform activity in the brain

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with a history of partial seizures following a traumatic head injury several years ago. Despite being on anti-epileptic medications, he continues to experience breakthrough seizures. His physician orders a routine scalp-recorded EEG and an evaluation with Magnetoencephalography (MEG) to assess his cortical activity and plan further management. The EEG shows frequent epileptiform activity, but the patient is concerned about the long-term prognosis of his condition.
Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of routine EEG and MEG in assessing the prognosis of seizure disorders?
questions.solution:
• EEG can be used to assess the prognosis of seizure disorders. A normal EEG implies a better prognosis, whereas an abnormal EEG showing frequent epileptiform activity indicates a worse outcome, as it suggests ongoing abnormal cortical excitability and a higher likelihood of recurrent seizures.
  • Option A is incorrect because a normal EEG does not guarantee that a patient will not develop epilepsy, although it is associated with a better prognosis.
  • Option C is incorrect because EEG has not been shown to be useful in predicting epilepsy in patients with predisposing conditions such as head injury or brain tumor, as epileptiform activity can be present even in those who do not develop seizures.
  • Option D is incorrect because MEG can localize the source of epileptiform activity using mathematical techniques and can be combined with anatomical imaging (like MRI) to improve localization for surgical planning.

Key Takeaways:

  • A normal EEG suggests a better prognosis for seizure control, while frequent epileptiform activity on EEG indicates a worse outcome.
  • MEG can complement EEG by providing detailed localization of the epileptiform activity, which is particularly useful in pre-surgical evaluations.

questions.text: Which antiseizure medication has a half-life of 18-32 hours, is indicated for Dravet and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes, and has systemic side effects such as elevated transaminases and weight loss?
questions.solution:
• Cannabidiol(CBD) is a non-psychoactive compound derived from cannabis that has been approved for the treatment of Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, two severe forms of childhood epilepsy. It is used in patients who are refractory to conventional therapies.
  • Half-life: The half-life of cannabidiol ranges between 18 and 32 hours, depending on the patient's metabolism and other factors.
  • Systemic side effects: Common side effects include elevated liver transaminases(which may necessitate monitoring of liver function) and weight loss. These systemic side effects are more likely when cannabidiol is used in combination with other antiseizure medications like valproate.

Option A (Brivaracetam) is a newer anticonvulsant primarily used for focal seizures, and it is not specifically indicated for Dravet or Lennox-Gastaut syndromes.

Option C (Clonazepam) is a benzodiazepine used for seizure control but is associated more with sedation and is not the primary treatment for Dravet or Lennox-Gastaut syndromes.

Option D (Ethosuximide) is typically used for absence seizures and is not indicated for Dravet or Lennox-Gastaut syndromes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cannabidiol is indicated for treating Dravet and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes and has a half-life of 18-32 hours.
  • It is associated with side effects such as elevated liver transaminases and weight loss, requiring regular monitoring of liver function during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following classes of drugs is NOT typically associated with causing orthostatic hypotension (OH)?
questions.solution:
Orthostatic Hypotension (OH): Orthostatic hypotension (OH) is a condition where there is a significant drop in blood pressure upon standing, leading to symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, or even falls. It is defined clinically as a drop of at least 20 mmHg in systolic blood pressure or 10 mmHg in diastolic blood pressure within three minutes of standing.

Drugs Associated with OH: Several classes of medications can cause OH due to their effects on blood pressure regulation. These include:

  1. Diuretics:
    • Mechanism: Diuretics, such as furosemide or thiazides, increase urine output, leading to decreased blood volume and reduced blood pressure. The reduced circulatory volume can impair the body's ability to maintain blood pressure when changing positions, such as standing.
    • Example: Loop diuretics (furosemide), thiazide diuretics (hydrochlorothiazide).
  2. Antihypertensives:
    • Mechanism: These drugs are used to treat high blood pressure but may lower blood pressure excessively, particularly when the body transitions from a lying or sitting position to standing.
    • Examples: Beta-blockers (metoprolol), alpha-blockers (prazosin), calcium channel blockers (amlodipine).
  3. Antidepressants:
    • Mechanism: Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) and monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) affect the balance of neurotransmitters, leading to vasodilation or reduced vascular tone, contributing to OH.
    • Examples: Amitriptyline (TCA), phenelzine (MAOI).
  4. Antibiotics:
    • Mechanism: Unlike the other drug classes mentioned, antibiotics do not typically interfere with blood pressure regulation, making them less likely to cause OH.
    • Examples: Penicillin, azithromycin.

Key Takeaway: Medications that lower blood volume or cause vasodilation are most likely to cause OH. Antibiotics do not typically cause OH as they don't impact the circulatory system in this way.

questions.text: Orthostatic hypotension (OH) is defined as a sustained drop in systolic blood pressure of at least ____ mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least ____ mmHg after 3 minutes of standing.
questions.solution:
Definition: Orthostatic hypotension (OH) is a condition characterized by an abnormal drop in blood pressure upon standing. It is clinically defined as a drop in systolic blood pressure by ≥20 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure by ≥10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing upright from a seated or lying position. This can lead to symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness and even fainting.

Physiology Behind OH:

  • In a normal physiological response, standing up causes blood to pool in the lower extremities due to gravity. This results in reduced venous return to the heart, decreasing cardiac output.
  • The body compensates by activating the sympathetic nervous system, which increases heart rate and vasoconstriction, thereby maintaining blood pressure.
  • In orthostatic hypotension, this compensatory mechanism fails due to various causes such as dehydration, medication effects, or autonomic dysfunction, leading to inadequate blood pressure control during postural changes.

Causes of OH:

  1. Volume depletion: Due to dehydration or blood loss, leading to a reduced circulatory volume.
  2. Medications: Diuretics, antihypertensives, and antidepressants can cause a drop in blood pressure.
  3. Autonomic failure: Seen in neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's or multiple system atrophy, where there is failure of autonomic control.
  4. Age-related changes: Elderly individuals are at higher risk due to decreased baroreceptor sensitivity and reduced cardiovascular adaptability.

Symptoms of OH:

  • Dizziness
  • Light-headedness
  • Blurred vision
  • Weakness
  • Fainting (syncope)

Diagnostic Approach:

  • Blood Pressure Measurement: Standing blood pressure should be compared with blood pressure after 3 minutes of standing.
  • Tilt Table Testing: In cases where OH is suspected but not confirmed by standing blood pressure measurements, tilt table testing can be used to assess the body's response to changes in position.

Key Takeaway: OH, is defined by specific blood pressure drops and can be caused by several mechanisms, including volume depletion, autonomic dysfunction and medication use. It is a common cause of syncope and requires careful management, especially in elderly or autonomically impaired individuals.

questions.text: In neurogenic Orthostatic Hypotension, the pulse fails to rise despite the drop in BP.Which condition might this indicate?
questions.solution:
Definition: Neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (OH) is a subtype of OH where the drop in blood pressure is due to autonomic nervous system dysfunction, particularly a failure of the sympathetic adrenergic system to adequately compensate for postural changes.

Pathophysiology: In a healthy individual, standing up triggers a reflex that increases heart rate and causes vasoconstriction to maintain blood pressure. In neurogenic OH, this response is impaired due to dysfunction in the sympathetic nervous system, leading to a failure in vasoconstriction and pulse increase.

Common Causes of Neurogenic OH:

  1. Parkinson's disease: Neurodegenerative disorders can affect the autonomic nervous system, causing neurogenic OH.
  2. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA): A condition where both the autonomic nervous system and motor system are affected.
  3. Pure Autonomic Failure: A rare disorder where only the autonomic nervous system is affected.
  4. Diabetic Autonomic Neuropathy: Long-term diabetes can lead to nerve damage affecting autonomic control of blood pressure.

Key Diagnostic Feature: In neurogenic OH, the heart rate does not increase appropriately upon standing, distinguishing it from non-neurogenic causes such as hypovolemia, where the pulse would rise as a compensatory mechanism.

Symptoms:

  • The same as general OH, but with a more pronounced failure to respond to postural changes.
  • Fatigue, cognitive impairment and visual disturbances can also occur.

Management:

  • Non-Pharmacological: Increased salt intake, compression stockings, and head-up tilt sleeping may help manage symptoms.
  • Pharmacological: Medications such as fludrocortisone (which increases blood volume) or midodrine (which increases vascular tone) can be prescribed.

Key Takeaway: In neurogenic OH, sympathetic adrenergic dysfunction prevents a rise in pulse despite the drop in blood pressure. This condition is associated with autonomic dysfunction seen in diseases like Parkinson's or multiple system atrophy.

choices.text: Heart rate variation with deep breathing

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to assess the parasympathetic component of cardiovascular reflexes via the vagus nerve?
questions.solution:
Cardiovascular Reflexes: The autonomic nervous system controls cardiovascular reflexes, which involve both sympathetic and parasympathetic components. The parasympathetic system is primarily responsible for slowing the heart rate and regulating resting cardiovascular function.

Parasympathetic Function Test:

  1. Heart Rate Variation with Deep Breathing:
    • This test assesses the parasympathetic nervous system via the vagus nerve. The heart rate normally increases during inspiration and decreases during expiration, a phenomenon known as respiratory sinus arrhythmia.
    • A reduced variation in heart rate during deep breathing indicates parasympathetic dysfunction.
    • Procedure: The patient is instructed to take slow deep breaths at a rate of 6 breaths per minute while heart rate variability is measured.
  2. Valsalva Maneuver: This test assesses both sympathetic and parasympathetic reflexes but is not specific for parasympathetic function alone.
  3. Tilt Table Testing: This evaluates the autonomic response to positional changes but is more focused on detecting orthostatic hypotension.
  4. Quantitative Sudomotor Axon Reflex Test (QSART): This evaluates the autonomic control of sweating, which involves both sympathetic and parasympathetic pathways, but primarily assesses sympathetic sudomotor function.

Key Takeaway: Heart rate variation with deep breathing is the best test for evaluating parasympathetic function as it directly reflects the vagal modulation of heart rate.

choices.text: Autoantibodies against the α3 subunit of the ganglionic Ach receptor are considered diagnostic of AAG
Seronegative Autoimmune Autonomic Neuropathy (SAAN) is confirmed when no autoantibodies are present against the α3 subunit, but its distinction from AAG is still unclear
Pathology shows preferential involvement of large myelinated nerve fibres in both AAG and SAAN
AAG can be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as small-cell carcinoma of the lung, adenocarcinoma, or thymoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Autoimmune Autonomic Ganglionopathy (AAG) and Seronegative Autoimmune Autonomic Neuropathy (SAAN) is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Option C is Incorrect: The pathology of Autoimmune Autonomic Ganglionopathy (AAG) and Seronegative Autoimmune Autonomic Neuropathy (SAAN) shows preferential involvement of small unmyelinated nerve fibers, with sparing of larger myelinated fibers. This is a key feature distinguishing the autonomic dysfunction in these conditions.

Option A is Correct: The presence of autoantibodies against the α3 subunit of the ganglionic acetylcholine receptor (AChR) is considered diagnostic for AAG. These antibodies play a key role in the disease mechanism.

Option B is Correct: In the absence of α3 subunit antibodies, cases are classified as Seronegative Autoimmune Autonomic Neuropathy (SAAN), though it is unclear if these conditions are distinct from AAG.

Option D is Correct: AAG can occur in association with paraneoplastic syndromes, particularly with malignancies such as small-cell carcinoma of the lung, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma, or thymoma.

Option E is Correct: Immunotherapy with agents such as plasmapheresis, intravenous immune globulin, glucocorticoids, rituximab, and mycophenolate mofetil has shown therapeutic benefit in managing AAG.

Key Takeaways:

  1. AAG involves autonomic failure with autoantibodies against the α3 subunit of the ganglionic AChR, and SAAN lacks these antibodies.
  2. Small unmyelinated nerve fibers are affected in AAG and SAAN, not large myelinated fibers.
  3. Paraneoplastic AAG is often linked with specific cancers, particularly small-cell lung carcinoma.
  4. Immunotherapies like plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective in some cases of AAG.
